sen.j: 大隈 重信（おおくま しげのぶ、天保9年2月16日 (旧暦)（1838年3月11日） - 大正11年（1922年）1月10日）は、日本の武士・佐賀藩士、政治家、教育者。
sen.e: Shigenobu OKUMA (February 16, 1838-January 10, 1922) was a federal retainer of the Saga clan who was a Japanese warrior, a statesman, and an educator.
Shigenobu OKUMA (February 16, 1838-January 10, 1922) was a federal retainer of the Saga clan who was a Japanese warrior, a statesman, and an educator.
Shigenobu OKUMA (March 11, 1838-January 10, 1922) was a feudal retainer of the Saga clan who was a Japanese warrior, a statesman, and an educator.
sen.cmt: 旧暦→新暦に修正、federal retainer→feudal retainerに修正、余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 第8代、第17代内閣総理大臣。
sen.e: The 8th and the 17th Prime Minister.
He was the 8th and the 17th Prime Minister.
He was the 8th and the 17th Prime Minister.

sen.j: 位階勲等は従一位大勲位。
sen.e: The ranks and orders that he was conferred was Junior First Rank, Supreme Order.
The ranks and orders that he was conferred was Junior First Rank, Supreme Order.
The ranks and orders that he was conferred was Junior First Rank, Supreme Order.

sen.j: 爵位は侯爵。
sen.e: The peerage was Marquis.
He was a Marquis.
He was a Marquis.

sen.j: 東京専門学校（現早稲田大学）の創立者。
sen.e: The founder of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University)
He was the founder of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University)
He was the founder of Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University).
sen.cmt: ピリオド追加、余分なスペース削除しました。

sen.j: 身長は180cmあった。
sen.e: His height was 180 centimeters tall.
His height was 180 centimeters tall.
His height was 180 centimeters tall.

sen.j: 佐賀城下会所小路（現：佐賀市水ヶ江）に、佐賀藩士の大隈信保・三井子夫妻の長男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born as the oldest son of Nobuyasu OKUMA, a feudal retainer of the Saga clan and Miiko in Saga castle town Kaisho-koji alley (current Mizugae, Saga city.)
He was born the oldest son of Nobuyasu OKUMA, a feudal retainer of the Saga clan, and Miiko, in the Saga castle town Kaisho-koji alley (current Mizugae, Saga city).
He was born the oldest son of Nobuyasu OKUMA, a feudal retainer of the Saga clan, and Miiko, in the Saga castle town Kaisho-koji alley (current Mizugae, Saga City).
sen.cmt: cityの頭文字を大文字に変更しました。

sen.j: 幼名は八太郎。
sen.e: His childhood name was Yataro.
His childhood name was Yataro.
His childhood name was Yataro.

sen.j: 大隈家は、知行300石を食み石火矢頭人（砲術長） を務める上士の家柄であった。
sen.e: The family lineage of OKUMA was Joshi (superior warrior) who got enfeoffment of 300 koku and worked as Ishibiya-tonin (captain of gunnery.)
The family lineage of OKUMA was that of Joshi (superior warrior) who got a fiefdom of 300 koku and worked as Ishibiya-tonin (captain of gunnery).
sen.cmt: Wording. Sorry but I don't think anybody would know what "enfeoffment" meant. Probably need to explain "koku" as well
sen.e: The family lineage of Okuma was that of Joshi (superior warrior) who got a fiefdom of 300 koku and worked as Ishibiya-tonin (captain of gunnery).

sen.j: 重信は7歳で藩校弘道館に入学し、佐賀の特色である『葉隠』に基づく儒教教育を受けるが、これに反発し、安政元年（1854年）に同志とともに藩校の改革を訴えた。
sen.e: Shigenobu entered the hanko (domain school) Kodokan school when he was 7 years old, then had education of Confucianism based on "Hagakure (the book of Bushido)" which was characteristics of Saga prefecture, but he objected it and appealed to reform Hanko with his comrades in 1854.

Shigenobu entered the hanko (domain school) Kodokan school when he was 7 years old, and was educated in Confucianism based on "Hagakure (the book of Bushido)" which was characteristic of Saga prefecture, but he objected to it and appealed to reform the Hanko with his comrades in 1854.

Shigenobu entered the hanko (domain school) Kodokan school when he was seven years old, and was educated in Confucianism based on "Hagakure" (the book of Bushido) which was characteristic of Saga Prefecture, but he objected to it and appealed to reform the hanko with his comrades in 1854.
sen.cmt: 7をスペルアウト、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、位置を移動、表記統一のためHanko→hankoとし、prefectureの頭文字を大文字に変更しました。

sen.j: 安政2年（1855年）に、弘道館を南北騒動をきっかけに退学、後に復学を許されたが戻らず、この頃、枝吉神陽から国学を学ぶ。
sen.e: The North-South commotion was a start of his leaving Kodokan school in 1855, he denied the permission of returning later, then he learned the study of Japanese culture and spirit from Shinyo EDAYOSHI.

The North-South commotion was the impetus for his leaving the Kodokan school in 1855; he was allowed to return thereafter but he rejected the offer, studying Japanese literature and culture afterwards under Shinyo EDAYOSHI instead.

The North-South commotion was the impetus for his leaving the Kodokan school in 1855; he was allowed to return thereafter but he rejected the offer, studying Japanese literature and culture afterwards under Shinyo EDAYOSHI instead.

sen.j: 安政3年（1856年）、佐賀藩蘭学寮に転じた。
sen.e: He transferred to Rangakuryo school (school to learn Western studies in Dutch) in Saga Domain in 1856.
He transferred to the Rangakuryo school (school to learn Western studies in Dutch) in Saga Domain in 1856.
He transferred to the Rangakuryo school (school to learn Western studies in Dutch) in the Saga Domain in 1856.

sen.j: のち文久元年（1861年）、鍋島直正にオランダの憲法について進講し、また、蘭学寮を合併した弘道館教授に着任、蘭学を講じた。
sen.e: He lectured Naomasa NABESHIMA on Dutch constitution in 1861, and he worked as the instructor lecturing the Western learning in Dutch at Kodokan school which merged Rangakuryo school.
He lectured Naomasa NABESHIMA on the Dutch constitution in 1861, and he worked as the instructor teaching Western studies in Dutch at the Kodokan school which merged with the Rangakuryo school.
He lectured Naomasa NABESHIMA on the Dutch constitution in 1861, and he worked as the instructor teaching Western studies in Dutch at the Kodokan school which merged with the Rangakuryo school.

sen.j: 大隈は、長州藩への協力および江戸幕府と長州藩の調停の斡旋を説いたが、藩政に影響するには至らなかった。
sen.e: OKUMA appealed the cooperation to Choshu Domain and the mediation between Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Choshu Domain, but he could not influence the Saga Domain politics.

OKUMA appealed for cooperation in the Choshu Domain and mediation between the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Choshu Domain, but he could not influence Saga Domain politics.

Okuma appealed for cooperation in the Choshu Domain and mediation between the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and Choshu Domain, but he could not influence Saga Domain politics.

sen.j: そして慶応元年（1865年）、佐賀藩が長崎の五島町にあった諌早藩士山本家屋敷を改造した佐賀藩校英学塾「致遠館」（校長：宣教師グイド・フルベッキ）にて、副島種臣と共に教頭格となって指導に当たった。
sen.e: He moved to 'Chienkan school' (Principal : a missionary Guido Herman Fridolin Verbeek) which was Saga Domain school to learn Western studies in English, reformed a residence of a feudal retainer of the Isahaya clan Yamamoto family in Goto city, Nagasaki prefecture, and worked as the same rank as vice-principal with Taneomi SOEJIMA.

He moved to 'Chienkan school' (the principal was a missionary named Guido Herman Fridolin Verbeek), which was a Saga Domain school to learn Western studies in English, remodelled the residence of the feudal retainer of the Isahaya clan Yamamoto family in Goto city, Nagasaki prefecture, and served along with Taneomi SOEJIMA with the same rank of vice-principal.

He moved to 'Chienkan school' (the principal was a missionary named Guido Herman Fridolin VERBEEK), which was a Saga Domain school to learn Western studies in English, remodelled the residence of the feudal retainer of the Isahaya clan Yamamoto family in Goto Town, Nagasaki, and served along with Taneomi SOEJIMA with the same rank of vice-principal.
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、仕様書に基づき、Guido Herman Fridolin Verbeek→Guido Herman Fridolin VERBEEKに修正、Goto city, Nagasaki prefecture→Goto Town, Nagasakiとしました。

sen.j: またフルベッキに英語を学んだ。
sen.e: Also he learned English from Verbeek.
He also learned English from Verbeek.
He also learned English from Verbeek.

sen.j: このとき新約聖書やアメリカ独立宣言を知り、大きく影響を受けた。
sen.e: Then he learned the New Testament and the Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America and was fairly influenced.
He also studied the New Testament and the Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America at that time, which influenced him greatly.
He also studied the New Testament and the Unanimous Declaration of the thirteen United States of America at that time, which influenced him greatly.

sen.j: また京都や長崎に往来して、尊王派として活動した。
sen.e: He went to Kyoto and Nagasaki frequently working as a royalist.
He frequently went to Kyoto and Nagasaki as an active Imperialist.
sen.cmt: Wording: not sure if Royalist is indeed better than Imperialist.
sen.e: He frequently went to Kyoto and Nagasaki as an active Imperialist.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）、副島と共に征夷大将軍 徳川慶喜に大政奉還を勧めることを計画し、脱藩して京都へ赴いたが、捕縛の上、佐賀に送還され、1か月の謹慎処分を受けた。
sen.e: He made a plan with SOEJIMA to advise Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians) for Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then escaped from the Saga Domain and went to Kyoto, however, he was arrested and repatriated to Saga and ordered not to leave his house for a month.

He made a plan with SOEJIMA to advise Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, Seiitaishogun (commander-in-chief of the expeditionary force against the barbarians) in the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then fled from Saga Domain and went to Kyoto, however, he was arrested and repatriated to Saga and ordered not to leave his house for a month.

He made a plan with Soejima to advise Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA, Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") in the Taisei Hokan (transfer of power back to the Emperor), then fled from Saga Domain and went to Kyoto, however, he was arrested and repatriated to Saga and ordered not to leave his house for a month.
sen.cmt: SOEJIMA→Soejimaとし、「征夷大将軍」を統一リストの表記に修正しました。

sen.j: 明治維新に際しては明治元年（1868年）、徴士参与職、外国事務局判事に任ぜられた。
sen.e: At the Meiji restoration in 1868, he was appointed to the judge of foreign affairs which was a position of Choshi sanyo (a councilor of feudal retainer of domain at government post).
At the time of the Meiji restoration in 1868, he was appointed to judge of foreign affairs, which was a position of Choshi sanyo (a councilor of the feudal retainer of the domain at government post).
sen.cmt: I couldn't find "徴士参与" in the List of Standardized Terms so I'm not really sure what that is supposed to say.
sen.e: At the time of the Meiji restoration in 1868, he was appointed to judge of foreign affairs, which was a position of Choshi sanyo (a councilor of the feudal retainer of the domain at government post).

sen.j: キリスト教禁令についてのイギリス公使ハリー・パークスとの交渉などで手腕を発揮するとともに、明治2年（1869年）からは会計官副知事を兼務し、高輪談判の処理や新貨条例の制定などの金融行政にも携わった。
sen.e: He showed the ability at the negotiation with English minister Harry Parks on the prohibition against Christianity, also, he concurrently held the post of vice governor of account from 1869, engaged in the handling of Takanawa negotiation and the financial administration such as establishment of New Currency Regulation.

He showed his abilities in negotiation with English minister Harry Parks on the prohibition of Christianity, also, he concurrently held the post of vice governor of accounts from 1869, engaged in the handling of the Takanawa negotiation and financial administration such as the establishment of the New Currency Regulation.

He showed his abilities in negotiation with English minister Harry PARKS on the prohibition of Christianity, also, he concurrently held the post of vice governor of accounts from 1869, engaged in the handling of the Takanawa negotiation and financial administration such as the establishment of the New Currency Regulation.
sen.cmt: Harry Parks→Harryr PARKSに修正しました。

sen.j: 明治3年（1870年）に参議に補され、明治6年（1873年）5月、大蔵省事務総裁、10月から参議兼大蔵卿になった。
sen.e: He was appointed the Councilor in 1870, then became the president of affairs at Ministry of Finance in May 1873, held the post of the Councilor and the Director General of the Ministry of Finance concurrently from October.

He was appointed the Councilor in 1870, then became the president of affairs at the Ministry of Finance in May 1873, holding the posts of the Councilor and the Director General of the Ministry of Finance concurrently from October.

He was appointed the Councilor in 1870, then became the president of affairs at the Ministry of Finance in May 1873, holding the posts of the Councilor and the Director General of the Ministry of Finance concurrently from October.

sen.j: 大隈の下には伊藤博文や井上馨といった若手官僚が集まり、木戸孝允とも結んで近代国家の早期建設を謳って大久保利通らを牽制した。
sen.e: Young bureaucrats such as Hirobumi ITO and Kaoru INOUE gathered to OKUMA, cooperating with Takayoshi KIDO, they appealed a construction of modern state in earlier period to check the activities of Toshimichi OKUBO and others.

Young bureaucrats such as Hirobumi ITO and Kaoru INOUE gathered around OKUMA, and in cooperation with Takayoshi KIDO, they appealed for the construction of a modern state in an earlier period in order to check the activities of Toshimichi OKUBO and others.

Young bureaucrats such as Hirobumi ITO and Kaoru INOUE gathered around Okuma, and in cooperation with Takayoshi KIDO, they appealed for the construction of a modern state in an earlier period in order to check the activities of Toshimichi OKUBO and others.

sen.j: 当時、伊藤や井上らが集って政治談義にふけった大隈の私邸をさして「築地梁山泊」と称した。
sen.e: OKUMA's private residence where ITO, INOUE and other young bureaucrats got together absorbing in the discussion of politics was called 'Tsukiji Ryozanpaku'.
OKUMA's private residence where ITO, INOUE and other young bureaucrats got together, absorbed in the discussion of politics, was called 'Tsukiji Ryozanpaku'.
Okuma's private residence where Ito, Inoue and other young bureaucrats got together, absorbed in the discussion of politics, was called 'Tsukiji Ryozanpaku.'
sen.cmt: OKUMA’s→Okuma's、ITO→Ito, INOUE→Inoueに修正、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、ピリオドの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 民部省を吸収合併させて大蔵省を一大官庁とした大隈は地租改正などの改革に当たるとともに、殖産興業政策を推進した。
sen.e: OKUMA who changed the Ministry of Finance to the important government by merging with the Ministry of the Treasury contributed to reformation such as the Reformed systems of land and tax fundamentally, and promoted the policy of the industry of local productions.

OKUMA, who changed the Ministry of Finance to an important government office by merging with the Ministry of the Treasury, was a fundamental contributor to reforms such as the Reformed systems of land and tax, and promoted the policy for local production industry.

Okuma, who changed the Ministry of Finance to an important government office by merging with the Ministry of the Treasury, was a fundamental contributor to reforms such as the Reformed systems of land and tax, and promoted the policy for local production industry.

sen.j: 征韓論には反対し、その後、殖産興業と財政改革という点から、明治8年（1875年）10月には、大久保利通と連名で財政についての意見書を太政官に提出したりしている。
sen.e: He objected Seikanron (the opinion to dispatch a mission to Korea), submitted a written opinion to Dajokan (cabinet) with Toshimichi OKUBO in their joint names on the industry of local productions and the financial reform in October 1875.

He opposed the Seikanron (the motion to send a mission to Korea), and submitted a written proposal to the Dajokan (cabinet) jointly with Toshimichi OKUBO on the promotion of local production industry and financial reform in October 1875.
sen.cmt: Wording. Not sure about the translation of "Seikanron"
sen.e: He opposed the Seikanron (debate on subjugation of Korea), and submitted a written proposal to the Dajokan (cabinet) jointly with Toshimichi OKUBO on the promotion of local production industry and financial reform in October 1875.
sen.cmt: Seikanronの補足を修正しました。(参照: 用語集、http://books.google.co.jp/books?id=RNycyM_xjDYC&pg=PA56&dq=seikanron&hl=ja&ei=samNTODlMYmEvgPVmvXnBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CDsQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=seikanron&f=false)

sen.j: また、単独でも財政の意見書を提出している。
sen.e: Also he submitted a written opinion on the financial matter by himself.
He also submitted a written proposal on financial matters by himself.
He also submitted a written proposal on financial matters by himself.

sen.j: さらに、西南戦争による支出費用の調達とその後の財政運営に携わった。
sen.e: Furthermore, he engaged in raising expenses by Seinan war and financial administration afterwards.
Moreover, he was engaged in raising expenses due to the Seinan war and in the financial administration afterwards.
Moreover, he was engaged in raising expenses due to the Seinan War and in the financial administration afterwards.

sen.j: 自由民権運動に同情して国会開設意見書を提出して早期の憲法公布と国会の即時開設を説いた。
sen.e: Having a compassion for the Democratic-rights movement submitted a written opinion for establishment of the National Diet and appealed the issuance of Constitution in earlier period and immediate establishment of the National Diet, and also conflict with his old friend ITO and Saccho (Satsuma and Choshu) force on the Affair of disposal of national property by Hokkaido Development Commissioner and misgovernment on financial affairs done by OKUMA himself led to the discharge of the Councilor in October 12, 1881.

Sympathizing with the Democratic-rights movement, he submitted a written proposal for the establishment of the National Diet and appealed for the issuance of the Constitution in an earlier period and the immediate establishment of the National Diet, and this along with conflict with his old friend ITO and the Saccho (Satsuma and Choshu) forces related to national property disposal by the Hokkaido Development Commissioner and the misgovernment of financial affairs done by OKUMA himself led to the discharge of the Councilor in October 12, 1881.
sen.cmt: Wording. This is still quite hard to read and would be better broken into 2 or 3 sentences.
sen.e: Sympathizing with the Democratic-rights movement, he submitted a written proposal for the establishment of the National Diet and appealed for the issuance of the Constitution in an earlier period and the immediate establishment of the National Diet.

sen.j: 一方、開拓使官有物払下げ事件を巡りかつての盟友である伊藤ら薩長勢と対立した。
sen.e: On the other hand, he had conflicts with his old friend Ito and the Satcho (Satsuma and Choshu) forces in relation to national property disposal by the Hokkaido Development Commissioner.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」一部訳文を修正、ITO→Ito、Saccho→Satchoとしました。

sen.j: 大隈自身の財政上の失政もあり、明治14年（1881年）10月12日、参議を免官となった。
sen.e: And the misgovernment of financial affairs done by Okuma himself led to the discharge of the Councilor in October 12, 1881.
sen.cmt: 「一原文一訳文の例外対処」OKUMA→Okumaとしました。

sen.j: いわゆる明治十四年の政変である。
sen.e: This is so called Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881).
This is the so-called Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881).
This is the so-called Meiji juyonen no seihen (the failed Meiji-14 coup of 1881).

sen.j: 大隈は、10月15日付で辞表を提出した。
sen.e: OKUMA submitted his resignation on October 15.
OKUMA submitted his resignation on October 15.
Okuma submitted his resignation on October 15.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、OKUMA→Okumaとしました。

sen.j: 明治13年（1880年）には、会計検査院創設のための建議をおこなっている。
sen.e: He gave a proposal for the foundation of Kaikeikensain (Board of Audit) in1880.
He submitted a proposal for the foundation of the Kaikeikensain (Board of Audit) in 1880.
He submitted a proposal for the foundation of the Kaikeikensain (Board of Audit) in 1880.

tit.e: After going into the opposition party
After going into the opposition party

sen.j: 野に下った大隈は、10年後の国会開設に備え、明治15年（1882年）3月には小野梓とともに立憲改進党を結成、尾崎行雄、犬養毅、矢野龍渓（龍渓）らが馳せ参じた。
sen.e: OKUMA who went into opposition formed the Constitutional Progressive Party with Azusa ONO in March 1882 for the establishment of the National Diet after 10 years, and Yukio OZAKI, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Ryukei YANO and others hasted to join.

OKUMA, who went into the opposition party, formed the Constitutional Progressive Party with Azusa ONO in March 1882 for the establishment of the National Diet 10 years later, and Yukio OZAKI, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Ryukei YANO and others hastened to join.

Okuma, who went into the opposition party, formed the Constitutional Progressive Party with Azusa ONO in March 1882 for the establishment of the National Diet 10 years later, and Yukio OZAKI, Tsuyoshi INUKAI, Ryukei YANO and others hastened to join.

sen.j: また10月、小野梓や高田早苗らと東京専門学校（現早稲田大学）を東京郊外の早稲田に開設した。
sen.e: He established Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University) with Azusa ONO, Sanae TAKATA and others in the suburb of Tokyo, Waseda.
He established Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University) with Azusa ONO, Sanae TAKATA and others in the suburbs of Tokyo, Waseda.
And in October, he established Tokyo Senmon Gakko (current Waseda University) with Azusa ONO, Sanae TAKATA and others in the suburbs of Tokyo, Waseda.
sen.cmt: 「また10月」→訳漏れのため訳出しました。

sen.j: 明治20年（1887年）、伯爵に叙された。
sen.e: He was given the Count in 1887.
He was made a Count in 1887.
He was made a Count in 1887.

tit.j: 外務大臣から総理大臣へ
tit.e: From Minister for Foreign Affairs to Prime Minister.
From Minister for Foreign Affairs to Prime Minister.
From Minister for Foreign Affairs to Prime Minister
tit.cmt: 余分なスペース削除、ピリオド削除しました。

sen.j: 大隈の外交手腕を評価する伊藤は、不平等条約改正のため、政敵である大隈を外務大臣 (日本)として選び、明治21年（1888年）2月より、大隈は外務大臣 (日本)に就任した。
sen.e: Evaluating OKUMA's ability for diplomacy, ITO chose his political enemy OKUMA as Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) for the revision of unequal treaty, he assumed the post of Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) in February 1888.

Appreciative of OKUMA's ability for diplomacy, ITO chose his political enemy OKUMA as the Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) for the revision of an unequal treaty, and he assumed the post of Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) in February 1888.

Appreciative of Okuma's ability for diplomacy, Ito chose his political enemy Okuma as the Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) for the revision of an unequal treaty, and he assumed the post of Minister of Foreign Affairs (Japan) in February 1888.

sen.j: 同年 黒田清隆が組閣すると大隈は留任するが、外国人判事を導入するという条約案が反対派の抵抗に遭い、明治22年（1889年）には国家主義組織玄洋社の一員である来島恒喜に爆弾による襲撃を受け、右脚を失うとともに、辞職した。
sen.e: When Kiyotaka KURODA formed a cabinet in the same year, OKUMA continued in office, but the treaty scheme including the introduction of foreign judges was resisted by the opposite factions, OKUMA received a bomb attacking by Tsuneki KURUSIMA, a member of Nationalism organization Genyosha in 1889, lost his right leg and resigned.

When Kiyotaka KURODA formed a cabinet in the same year, OKUMA continued in office, but the treaty plan which included the introduction of foreign judges was resisted by opposing factions, and OKUMA was attacked with a bomb by Tsuneki KURUSIMA, a member of the Nationalist organization Genyosha in 1889, lost his right leg and resigned.

When Kiyotaka KURODA formed a cabinet in the same year, Okuma continued in office, but the treaty plan which included the introduction of foreign judges was resisted by opposing factions, and Okuma was attacked with a bomb by Tsuneki KURUSIMA, a member of the Nationalist organization Genyosha in 1889, lost his right leg and resigned.

sen.j: 明治29年（1896年） 第2次松方内閣（「松隈内閣」（しょうわいないかく）と呼ばれる）で再び外相に就任するが薩摩藩勢と対立して明治30年（1897年）に辞職した。
sen.e: He assumed the post of Minister for Foreign Affairs again in 1896 at the second MATSUKATA cabinet (called 'SHOWAI [MATSUKATA and OKUMA]' cabinet,) but he opposed against Satsuma Domain force and resigned in 1897.

He assumed the post of Minister for Foreign Affairs again in 1896 during the second MATSUKATA cabinet (called the 'SHOWAI [MATSUKATA and OKUMA]' cabinet), but he opposed the Satsuma Domain force and resigned in 1897.

He assumed the post of Minister for Foreign Affairs again in 1896 during the second Matsukata Cabinet (called the 'SHOWAI [Matsukata and Okuma] Cabinet'), but he opposed the Satsuma clan force and resigned in 1897.
sen.cmt: the second MATSUKATA cabinet→the second Matsukata Cabinet、‘SHOWAI [MATSUKATA and OKUMA]’ cabinet→'SHOWAI [Matsukata and Okuma]' Cabinet、the Satsuma Domain force→the Satsuma clan forceとしました。

sen.j: 明治31年（1898年）6月に板垣退助らと憲政党を結成し、同年6月30日に藩閥以外からでは初の内閣総理大臣を拝命、日本初の政党内閣を組閣した。
sen.e: He formed the Constitutional Political Party with Taisuke ITAGAKI and others in June 1898, he received an official appointment as the first Prime Minister from out of domain clique, then formed the first political party Cabinet in Japan.

He formed the Constitutional Political Party with Taisuke ITAGAKI and others in June 1898, received an official appointment as the first Prime Minister from an out-of-domain faction, then formed the first political party Cabinet in Japan.

He formed the Constitutional Political Party with Taisuke ITAGAKI and others in June 1898, received an official appointment as the first Prime Minister from an out-of-domain faction, then formed the first political party Cabinet in Japan.

sen.j: 俗に言う「隈板内閣」（わいはんないかく）である。
sen.e: As is commonly said 'WAIHAN (OKUMA and ITAGAKI) cabinet.

sen.j: しかし旧自由党 (日本)と旧進歩党 (日本)の間に対立が生じ、また文相尾崎行雄が共和演説事件をきっかけに辞職すると後任人事をめぐって対立はさらに激化。
sen.e: However, the old Liberal party (Japan) and the old Progressive Party (Japan) opposed and Minister of Education Yukio OZAKI resigned due to the affair of Kyowa speech, the conflict became much severer over the personnel matter for the successor.

However, the old Liberal party (Japan) and the old Progressive Party (Japan) formed an opposition, and the Minister of Education, Yukio OZAKI, resigned due to the Kyowa speech affair, and antagonism concerning the succession of personnel became much more severe.
sen.cmt: It seems unnecessary to include (Japan). Wording
sen.e: However, the old Liberal Party (Japan) and the old Progressive Party (Japan) formed an opposition, and the Minister of Education, Yukio OZAKI, resigned due to the Kyowa Speech Affair, and antagonism concerning the succession of personnel became much more severe.
sen.cmt: Liberal Party、the Kyowa Speech Affairとしました。

sen.j: 後任文相に旧進歩党の犬養毅が就いたことに不満を持った旧自由党の星亨は、一方的に憲政党の解党を宣言、新たな憲政党を結成した。
sen.e: As Tsuyoshi INUKAI of the old Progressive Party was assumed the post of the next Minister of Education, Toru HOSHI of the old Liberal Party dissatisfied with the result, he declared one-sidedly the dissolution of the Constitutional Political Party, and formed a new Constitutional Political Party.

As Tsuyoshi INUKAI of the old Progressive Party assumed the post of the next Minister of Education, Toru HOSHI of the old Liberal Party, who was dissatisfied with the result, declared one-sidedly the dissolution of the Constitutional Political Party, and formed a new Constitutional Political Party.

As Tsuyoshi INUKAI of the old Progressive Party assumed the post of the next Minister of Education, Toru HOSHI of the old Liberal Party, who was dissatisfied with the result, declared one-sidedly the dissolution of the Constitutional Political Party, and formed a new Constitutional Political Party.

sen.j: 結局、組閣からわずか4ヶ月後の11月8日、内閣は総辞職する羽目となり、大隈は旧進歩党をまとめて憲政本党を率いることとなった。
sen.e: All in all, on November 8 just after 4 months from forming a cabinet, the Ministry resulted in resignation, OKUMA had to lead the New Constitutional Political Party organizing the old Progressive Party.

All in all, on November 8, just 4 months after the formation of the cabinet, the Ministry ended in resignation, and OKUMA had to lead the New Constitutional Political Party in organizing the old Progressive Party.
sen.cmt: Wording. This is rather unclear still.
sen.e: All in all, on November 8, just four months after the formation of the cabinet, the Ministry ended in resignation, and Okuma had to lead the New Constitutional Political Party in organizing the old Progressive Party.
sen.cmt: 4をスペルアウト、OKUMA→Okumaとしました。

sen.j: 明治40年（1907年）、いったん政界を引退し、早稲田大学総長への就任、大日本文明協会会長としてのヨーロッパ文献の日本語翻訳事業、南極探検隊後援会長への就任など、精力的に文化事業を展開した。
sen.e: He withdrew from the political world temporarily in 1907, he energetically developed the cultural businesses, such as assuming the post of the President of Waseda university, contribution to the translation project of European literatures as the President of the Great Japan Civilization Association, and assuming the post of the campaign club leader of the Antarctic exploration.

He withdrew from the political world temporarily in 1907 and put his energies into the development of cultural affairs, such as assuming the post of the President of Waseda university, contributing to the translation project of European literatures as the President of the Great Japan Civilization Association, and assuming the post of campaign club leader of the Antarctic exploration.

He withdrew from the political world temporarily in 1907 and put his energies into the development of cultural affairs, such as assuming the post of the President of Waseda University, contributing to the translation project of European literatures as the President of the Great Japan Civilization Association, and assuming the post of campaign club leader of the Antarctic exploration.

sen.j: 第一次護憲運動が興ると、政界に復帰した。
sen.e: He returned to the political world when the first Constitution protection movement broke out.
He returned to the political world when the first Constitution protection movement broke out.

sen.j: 大正3年（1914年）にはシーメンス事件で辞職した山本権兵衛の後を受けて、2度目の内閣を組織した。
sen.e: He formed the second cabinet in 1914 succeeding Gonbei YAMAMOTO who resigned for Siemens affair.
He formed his second cabinet in 1914, succeeding Gonbei YAMAMOTO, who resigned due to the Siemens affair.

sen.j: 与党は立憲同志会、大隈伯後援会および中正会である。

The ruling parties were Comrades for Constitution, while the support groups were for the Count OKUAMA, and Chuseikai.

sen.j: 7月、第一次世界大戦が起こると、中国大陸での権益確保を求めて、8月23日に対ドイツ宣戦布告をおこなった。
sen.e: In July when the First World War broke out, he declared war against Germany on August 23 appealing the rights and interests in the Chinese continent.
In July, when the First World War broke out, he declared war against Germany on August 23, seeking to preserve Japan's interests in the Chinese continent.
In July, when the First World War broke out, he declared war against Germany on August 23, seeking to preserve Japan's interests in the Chinese continent.

sen.j: 翌・大正4年（1915年）には外相 加藤高明と共に対華21ヶ条要求を提出した。
sen.e: The next year in 1915 he submitted Twenty-one Demands with the Minister of Foreign Affairs Takaaki KATO.
In 1915, the next year he submitted Twenty-one Demands with the Minister of Foreign Affairs, Takaaki KATO.

sen.j: しかし内相 大浦兼武の汚職事件（大浦事件）が起こると、8月には自身が外務大臣を兼任するなどして内閣を改造するも、内閣は次第に国民の支持を失っていった。
sen.e: However the scandal of the Interior Minister Kanetake OURA (Oura affair) happened, OKUMA currently held the post of the Minister of Foreign Affairs in August and reshuffled the cabinet, but the cabinet began to lose the support by the people.

However, when the scandal of the Interior Minister, Kanetake OURA (Oura affair) arose, OKUMA, who held the post of Minister of Foreign Affairs in August, reshuffled the cabinet, but the cabinet began to lose public support.

However, when the scandal of the Interior Minister, Kanetake OURA (the Oura Affair) arose, Okuma, who held the post of Minister of Foreign Affairs in August, reshuffled the Cabinet, but the cabinet began to lose public support.
sen.cmt: 余分なスペース消去、the Oura Affair、the Cabinet、OKUMA→Okumaとしました。

sen.j: さらに内閣に対する元老の圧迫が激しさを増し、大正5年（1916年）10月ついに内閣は総辞職、あわせて政界から完全に引退した。
sen.e: Furthermore, Genro (elder statesman) gave pressure harder and harder against the cabinet, the Ministry resigned finally in October 1916, OKUMA fully retired the political world.

Furthermore, Genro (elder statesman) put more and more pressure on the cabinet, and when the Ministry resigned finally in October 1916, OKUMA fully retired for once and for all from the political world.

Furthermore, Genro (elder statesman) put more and more pressure on the Cabinet, and when the Ministry resigned finally in October 1916, Okuma fully retired for once and for all from the political world.

sen.j: 退任時の年齢は満78歳6ヶ月で、これは2009年現在も日本の歴代総理大臣中最高齢の記録である。
sen.e: He was 78 years and 6 months old when he retired, which is the oldest record of the age among the successive Prime Minister in Japan as of the year 2009.
He was 78 years and 6 months old when he retired, which is the oldest age on record among the successive Prime Ministers in Japan as of the year 2009.

sen.j: この間、大正5年7月に侯爵に叙された。

sen.j: 大正11年（1922年）1月10日に早稲田で死去、1月17日に自邸での告別式ののち、日比谷公園で未曾有の「国民葬」が催された。
sen.e: He died in January 10, 1922 in Waseda, the funeral service was held at his residence on January 17, then unprecedented "National Funeral" was held at Hibiya Park.

sen.j: その名が示すように式には約30万人の一般市民が参列、会場だけでなく沿道にも多数の市民が並んで大隈との別れを惜しんだ。
sen.e: As it said National, about 300,000 general citizens attended the funeral, and not only in the site but also on the street a lot of citizens stood and regretted the parting with OKUMA.
As the word "National" implies, about 300,000 general citizens attended the funeral, and many citizens not only at the site but also on the streets stood and regretted parting with OKUMA.
As the word "National" implies, about 300,000 general citizens attended the funeral, and many citizens not only at the site but also on the streets stood and regretted parting with Okuma.

sen.j: この三週間後に同じ日比谷公園で行われた山縣有朋の「国葬」では、山縣の不人気を反映して政府関係者以外は人影もまばらで「まるで官葬か軍葬」と言われ、翌日の東京日日新聞は「民抜きの国葬で、幄舎の中はガランドウの寂しさ」と報じたほどだった。
sen.e: The State Funeral of Aritomo YAMAGATA was held at the same site, Hibiya Park 3 weeks later, which reflecting his unpopularity, there were few people except for the persons concerned the government, so it was said 'It is like a bureaucrat or military funeral', and reported by the Tokyo Nichinichi journal the next day 'It was the state funeral without the people, so the empty tents brought the lonesome.'

The State Funeral of Aritomo YAMAGATA was held at the same site, Hibiya Park, three weeks later, which reflected his relative unpopularity, as there were few people apart from those who were affiliated with the government, so it was said to be 'like a bureaucrat or military funeral', and as reported by the Tokyo Nichinichi journal the next day, 'it was a state funeral without the people, so the empty tents brought lonesome feelings.'

The State Funeral of Aritomo YAMAGATA was held at the same site, Hibiya Park, three weeks later, which reflected his relative unpopularity, as there were few people apart from those who were affiliated with the government, so it was said to be 'like a bureaucrat or military funeral,' and as reported by the Tokyo Nichinichi journal the next day, 'it was a state funeral without the people, so the empty tents brought lonesome feelings.'
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、カンマの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 墓所は佐賀市の龍泰寺と東京都文京区の護国寺にある。

sen.j: 伊藤博文をライバル視していたことがよく知られており、以下のようなエピソードが伝えられている。
sen.e: It is widely known that OKUMA regarded Hirobumi ITO as his rival, so some following episodes have been coming down.

It is widely known that Okuma regarded Hirobumi ITO as his rival, and so certain related episodes have been passed down.

sen.j: 明治30年（1897年）に大磯町に別邸を構えたが、この別荘から西へわずか60メートルの地所には、当時、伊藤が本邸を構えていた。
sen.e: OKUMA settled the second residence in Oiso city in 1897, then ITO had his residence just 60 meters away to the west from that second residence.
OKUMA settled into a second residence in Oiso city in 1897; at that time ITO had his own residence just 60 meters west of it.
Okuma settled into a second residence in Oiso Town in 1897; at that time Ito had his own residence just 60 meters west of it.

sen.j: 様々な政治上の軋轢があった相手との近い距離のためか、大磯別邸はあまり使用されず、明治40年（1907年）には別邸を新たに国府津に構え、わずか10年で大磯を引き払っている。
sen.e: As ITO who conflicted on the political matter lived near to OKUMA's second residence in Oiso, OKUMA rarely used there, so he settled another second residence in Kozu, he vacated the residence in Oiso jus 10 year later.

As ITO, who was often in conflict with him on political matters, lived near OKUMA's second residence in Oiso, OKUMA rarely used the house, and so he settled into another second residence in Kozu, vacating his residence in Oiso just 10 years later.

As Ito, who was often in conflict with him on political matters, lived near Okuma's second residence in Oiso, Okuma rarely used the house, and so he settled into another second residence in Kozu, vacating his residence in Oiso just 10 years later.

sen.j: 大隈と同郷で、かれに目をかけられた行政法学者織田萬のエッセイ集『法と人』（1943年、春秋社教養叢書）によると、早稲田大学開学式典で伊藤が「大隈君とはいろいろ競ってきたが、教育機関を自ら作ったという点ではかなわない」と述べたことに満悦したという。
sen.e: According to the essay "Law and People" (Shunjusha Publishing Company educational library in 1943) written by Yorozu ODA, a scholar of administrative law, who was from the same province as OKUMA and favored by him, he was satisfied with the speech of ITO given at the opening ceremony of Waseda university 'Although I conflicted with OKUMA in a various matters, I cannot touch him as he built the educational institute by himself.'

According to the essay "Law and People" (Shunjusha Publishing Company educational library, 1943) written by Yorozu ODA, a scholar of administrative law, who was from the same province as OKUMA and favored by him, he was satisfied with the speech ITO gave at the opening ceremony of Waseda University in which he said, 'although I have been in conflict with OKUMA over various matters, the fact that he built this educational institute by himself is beyond reproach.'

According to the essay "Law and People" (Shunjusha Publishing Company educational library, 1943) written by Yorozu ODA, a scholar of administrative law, who was from the same province as Okuma and favored by him, he was satisfied with the speech Ito gave at the opening ceremony of Waseda University in which he said, 'although I have been in conflict with Okuma over various matters, the fact that he built this educational institute by himself is beyond reproach.'
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、OKUMA→Okuma、ITO→Itoとしました。

sen.j: また伊藤がハルビンで暗殺されると、「なんと華々しい死に方をしたものか」と悲しみつつも本気でうらやんだとのことである。
sen.e: When ITO was murdered in Harbin, OKUMA was sorrowed but envied him saying 'How he could die gloriously'.
When ITO was murdered in Harbin, OKUMA was sorrowed but also envious, saying 'he was able to die so gloriously'.
When Ito was murdered in Harbin, Okuma was sorrowed but also envious, saying 'he was able to die so gloriously.'
sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、OKUMA→Okuma、ITO→Itoとし、ピリオドの位置を移動しました。

sen.j: 大正8年（1919年）、病床にあった成瀬仁蔵を励ますために、トマトやメロンをもって見舞った。
sen.e: OKUMA visited Jinzo NARUSE in his bed to encourage him with tomatoes and melons in 1919.
OKUMA brought tomatos and melons and visited Jinzo NARUSE in his sickbed to encourage him in 1919.

sen.j: 口癖は「何々であるんである」。
sen.e: He had the habit of saying to repeat the conclusion twice.

sen.j: 早稲田大学非常勤講師の佐藤能丸は、このことが今日に至るまで大隈の全集が発行されていない遠因となっていると指摘している。
sen.e: Yoshimaru SATO, a part-time teacher at Waseda university, pointed that his circumstance is a remote cause that there is no publishing of the library of OKUMA until today.
Yoshimaru SATO, a part-time teacher at Waseda university, pointed out that this was an underlying cause of why OKUMA's library had not been published until the present day.

sen.j: 極めて合理的な考えを持っており、日本の暦を現在使われているグレゴリオ暦に変えた。
sen.e: He was quite rational, so he changed the calendar in Japan to the Gregorian calendar that we currently use.

sen.j: 英雄を認めず、そのためか西郷隆盛を全く認めていない。
sen.e: He did not admit heroes, so that he did not admit Takamori SAIGO at all.
He did not recognize people as heroes, and thus he did not recognize Takamori SAIGO as a hero whatsoever.
He did not recognize people as heroes, and thus he did not recognize Takamori SAIGO as a hero whatsoever.

sen.j: 一方、西郷も大隈を「俗吏」とみなして嫌っていたとされ、特に明治4年（1871年）の西郷上京の際に書かれた「西郷吉之助意見書」では名指しこそ避けたものの大隈の政策を「武士のやること」ではないと切捨て、更に同年に西郷の推挙で大蔵省入りした安場保和が大隈への弾劾意見書を提出したこと（西郷も大久保もこれには反対したために却下された）によって、大隈の西郷への反感は抜きがたいものになったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that SAIGO also hated OKUMA as 'snobbish public servant', and in 'The written opinion by Kuranosuke SAIGO' which he wrote before coming to Tokyo in 1871 that, although he did not appointed the name directly, he criticized the policy of OKUMA was 'not the policy of warriors', then Yasukazu YASUBA who entered the Ministry of Finance the same year with the recommendation by SAIGO submitted the impeachment written opinion to OKUMA (This was rejected because both SAIGO and OKUBO opposed it.), the antipathy to SAIGO from OKUMA became much stronger.

It is said that SAIGO also hated OKUMA as a 'snobbish public servant', and in 'The written opinions of Kuranosuke SAIGO', which he wrote before coming to Tokyo in 1871, although he did not directly mention him by name, he criticized OKUMA's policy as one which was 'not the policy of warriors', and then Yasukazu YASUBA, who entered the Ministry of Finance the same year with the recommendation of SAIGO, submitted a written proposal for the impeachment of OKUMA (which was rejected because both SAIGO and OKUBO opposed it.), making OKUMA's antipathy towards SAIGO much stronger.

It is said that Saigo also hated Okuma as a 'snobbish public servant,' and in 'The Written Opinions of Kuranosuke SAIGO,' which he wrote before coming to Tokyo in 1871, although he did not directly mention him by name, he criticized Okuma's policy as one which was 'not the policy of warriors,' and then Yasukazu YASUBA, who entered the Ministry of Finance the same year with the recommendation of Saigo, submitted a written proposal for the impeachment of Okuma (which was rejected because both Saigo and Okubo opposed it.), making Okuma's antipathy towards Saigo much stronger.
sen.cmt: SAIGO→Saigo、OKUMA→Okuma、OKUBO→Okuboとし、全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、カンマの位置を移動、The Written Opinions of Kuranosuke SAIGOとしました。

sen.j: しかし、大隈は西郷について、「人情には極めて篤かった」とも述べている。

However, OKUMA described SAIGO by saying 'he had a lot of heart'.

sen.cmt: 全角クォーテーションを半角に修正、カンマの位置を移動、SAIGO→Saigo、OKUMA→Okumaとしました。

sen.j: 昭和44年（1969年）から45年（1970年）にかけて、早稲田大学出版部で「大隈伯昔日譚」などが入った木村毅監修『大隈重信叢書』全5巻が出された。
